text:
We'll go ahead and get started. Welcome to the investing in
resiliency and security panel for our Silicon Valley and
US government speaker series.

I'm your moderator
for today's session. We have three incredible
panelists here today. So Dan Gwak managing
partner at Point72, also

heads up their entire
defense strategy. And he was also in the
Marine Corps as well. Paul Kwan over here, managing
director at General Catalyst.

He leads the global resilience
team for General Catalyst and was previously a
famous investment banker

at Morgan Stanley. Hall of fame, is
what I've heard. So, Steve-- A small world.

Steve Bowsher, CEO and President
of In-Q-Tel strategic venture fund for the US
intelligence community. He's been a pillar of In-Q-Tel
for nearly two decades now.

Quite a-- 18 years
and four weeks. Yep, yep. So lots of fun
connection points here.

One being In-Q-Tel . So I started my
career with a couple of folks who helped get
In-Q-Tel off the ground.

Steve of course,
leads In-Q-Tel . Dan actually worked
with Steve at In-Q-Tel for a number of years
before joining Point72.

Second connection
point is just-- GC wouldn't exist
without In-Q-Tel . Yeah. And that's another
connection point.

We also have several
shared investments as well. So Dan and I invest in
a company that you might have heard of called Shield AI.

And I believe Dan and
Paul invested in-- co-invested in
vandiver labs together.

And then Steve, Paul
and I have invested in Anduril industries, lots
of other co-investments, but that's a couple.

And the third
common connection is to the world's best University,
Stanford University, of course.

Oh, wait, except
for Dan, because he went to some random school
on in Boston somewhere.

So sorry about that-- I snuck in. This is the closest-- --Dan but-- --I get to Stanford. But on a more serious
note, all of us

here today have supported
founders, companies that are building products
and technologies that

are critical to national
security and resilience. I think one thing
that we've seen is technology has
become increasingly

important for economic
growth, military power to a number of nation states. And countries are, really,
competing to develop and control

key technologies where
in this technology war that's being fought
on multiple fronts. And being here,
in Silicon Valley,

really at the heart
of innovation, we're just seeing more and
more investment dollars being poured into
critical technologies

like AI, autonomy,
semiconductors, aerospace, advanced energy and more. And maybe we could just
start by discussing,

for the panelists, what
are the sectors that you're most excited about right
now, especially when we talk

about resilience and security. And what's your investment
thesis these days.

Paul, do you want
to kick us off? Sure so General Catalyst, 25
year venture capital firm.

Our focus is called resilience. So that's defense and intel,
industrial and energy.

We think these are the
most critical systems that haven't been modernized yet
with technology and software.

And then we take a
slightly different approach towards portfolio allocation.

So we think about
the broad spectrum of things we have to build
to get to the mission. And so we think a lot about--

because we do have
a lot of capital, are we investing appropriately
in big moonshots that

could take a lot of time but
be very significant in terms of the outcome. So we have a fusion
energy startup

that we funded almost
$1 billion into. We have a semiconductor moonshot
that Steve and I have funded.

Again, they might work, they
might not but if they do, they'll be transformative. Then you go through all the
seed series A, series B,

investing that all
four of us do together. And then on the far right,
we've actually done roll ups. Because we think that to do
industrial defense and energy,

sometimes you have to roll up
companies and do typical more creative approaches.

And so we've got a company
called Rebuild Manufacturing, which has rolled up about
13 advanced manufacturing

sites in America
into one conglomerate and is making really
good progress. And so I just
encourage all of you

to think about if you want
to solve these problems, it has to be much more creative
than just the typical hey,

let's start a company
and take some money. Sometimes you have
to find someone out there and merge with it. Sometimes you have to
partner with somebody.

Sometimes you have to
go after a moonshot. It's very, very different
how you approach this market segment.

Yeah. Happy to describe how
we see it at Point72.

We really are a US Defense
tech focused strategy. And, we think about
our investing mandate

as the startups today that can
shift the global superpower balance. And that's a high bar, right.

It's not a lot of companies
that are necessarily going to be able to do that. But the reason we define it that
way is because first of all,

I think we are at a
unique moment in time where the technologies of today
have that level of impact.

If you rewind like
10 years, 15 years, I think there was a
lot of emergent tech that had a huge impact
on consumer and commerce

and things like
that, but probably weren't going to move the
needle on the global superpower balance.

Today, when I think about things
like autonomy, for example, that absolutely can
have a causal impact

on whether the United States
maintains its dominance. And so that is the kind
of big picture thesis

that we invest behind. The second reason for that is,
of course, as venture investors, we have to look at things that
provide venture scale returns.

And you guys are
all at Stanford. I think you're probably a little
bit more advanced in thinking about this than some of
the East Coast schools
that Ernestine was referring to. But the reality is it's not--

raising venture dollars
and seeking an outcome is seeking an outcome
that's a billion

plus inside of a
reasonable time frame. That's a high bar. And that's not just about
building a successful business,

that's about building a
successful IPO scale business. And if you want to have
that kind of impact,

I think the bar needs
to be that it really is something that can rise
to the level of affecting

the superpower balance of today. So In-Q-Tel , we're investing
across five areas of technology.

The first one is
Enterprise Technology, which we're thinking
about renaming AI in some form or another,
because everything we're

doing in that space is AI. But, obviously, the
agencies we work with collect large amounts of
data so we need technology

to search it, store it,
integrate it, present it, visualize it. So we're investing
across all those areas.

The second is cyber
which technically you could argue is
Enterprise Technology but we've broken it out as a
standalone practice area for us.

The third is advanced systems. So think of these as anything
from the commercial space

platforms that a number
of us are investing in, to airborne platforms,
to unmanned, autonomous

platforms in the air, on the
ground, in the sea, underwater. The fourth area is
intelligent connectivity,

which would include
covert communications, it would include our
microelectronics stuff,

including the deal that
Paul referenced there. But a lot of our hardware
and microelectronics

and telecom or communications
stuff would fall on that. Then our fifth area is probably
a little bit of a surprise.

It's actually called
b.next or biology next. That's because we're
interested in biodefense.

We're interested in biosensors. And as engineered biology
becomes a more interesting

technology areas, we're
interested in some of the manufacturing
and other things you can do with engineered biology.

Has anything changed in
terms of how each of you have thought about NatSec
and defense tech investing

over the past year,
especially as we've seen recent conflicts
emerge across the world?

So I'll go first on that one. So I think a couple of
things have changed.

First is I'd say that the vast
majority of the years I've been at In-Q-Tel , we invested in
what we would characterize

as dual use technologies. So technologies that
were being developed for both the government world
and the commercial world.

Companies like Databricks,
FireEye, Cloudera, things of that nature would
be representative investments

for us. In the recent four
or five years, maybe going back longer
than just one year,

we've seen the rise of
a defense tech ecosystem here in the United
States, in which we're

seeing more and more
companies for whom the only government-- the
only customer market that they

want to serve is the government
market in some form or another. So in the first 10 or 12
years I was at In-Q-Tel ,

Palantir would be the only
example of a government-only company that we invested in.

Now, starting back in 2016-17,
you saw the second generation of those companies led by
Anduril but also Shield AI,

Skydio, Vannevar Labs, and a
number of other companies were founded in the last five or
seven years that are really

focusing only on the
government as a market. So that's certainly been one,
I think, meta change here.

The second, I would say, is
in the conflicts in Ukraine and in the Middle East
what we've obviously

seen is the rise of
drones, counter drones, electronic warfare.

New forms of covert
communication, new forms of aerial
collection, new forms

of autonomous platforms
being deployed, new forms of munitions.

So I think all those
areas, I just described, some of them we were investing
in before any of those conflicts

started, but they've
certainly become more intense areas of investment
since those conflicts have started.

And other areas, quite frankly,
we weren't investing in at all. And then as you turn towards a
potential conflict in the South

China Sea, is perhaps the
next conflict on the horizon, I think you see, some of
those same technologies

I just described are
certainly be applicable there. But what you also see, there
is a much-increased level

of interest in
Maritime-related technology. It's whether it is on
the surface or underwater

but certainly,
there's going to be a lot of demand for
technologies that can operate in those environments.

I think there's a lot
of hype around defense tech, industrial tech. There's a conference somewhere
in the US every week.

You can get a free
lunch somewhere. I think there's three
conferences on Wednesday just this week.

And it's exciting. It's awesome to have talent and
energy and focus and capital.

But I think there's
really three things that have changed my mind,
Ernestine, in the last year.

One is if you actually
talk to people that have been like at the
edge in Ukraine, people who've been there for weeks and talked
to some of the foreign advisors.

The pace of change
in Ukraine is insane. So I had the chance to meet a
very senior Western military

leader, and he said, listen,
I've been gone for a week, came out to Washington to
brief some of your friends.

And when I go back
after one week, everything will have changed. I will not know anything
about tactics and stuff.

And it's just that fast. You have to understand
that's how fast it is. And their fear is that all
of that operational learning

is going back via the Russians
to the Chinese and others. And so that's just to understand
the speed, the velocity

of learning and how all these
things move on this digitally connected battlefields. All the drones, all
the radar, all the EW,

it's very, very intense. The second thing is, when
you actually dig into it,

it's a multi-dimensional
battlefield, and there's opportunity
for everyone to contribute in some way.

This is something we talked
about last class, which is, yes, there's the land, sea
air, there's a cyber warfare,

there's a space warfare. But there's also
economic warfare, there's informational warfare.

And so you think about-- and then there's
the industrial base to build all those capabilities. And so when we
think about what do

we need to do to innovate and
modernize and work in people, either contribute, from
a startup standpoint

or from an energy standpoint,
it's on all of those dimensions. Energy. All of these things
feed into this stack

around much more resilient
capabilities, global resilience for each of us,
us and our allies.

And so the aperture
for what we have to do is much bigger than just
say, drones, and AI planes.

And the third piece is even
though we have capital now, we have experienced
investors who've served

and understand the
marketplace and have all that and people coming into
the energy space, sales and distribution
into the government

is really, really hard. There's probably 25 people that
have sold $1 billion of stuff

into the US-- the DOD. And so getting the right help
to sell into this environment

is very, very challenging. And so we were able to
start a new, kind of, Defense company, just two
weeks ago, which is called,

the CEO. And her team will help you
sell into the US government. And so that's someone
you would never

get to hire unless you
were a big, big company. And she's going to start a
whole platform that helps too.

So again, selling is not to
be trivialized in this market, especially for those
who have experience. But if we can take out some
of those friction points,

then we can start to
unlock the innovation. Yeah. In the last 12 months,
I'd point to two things.

One is a market innovation
that I would call probably boring but important. And then the other one
is a doctrine innovation

that I'd probably call
scary and also important. On the market side, it's
kind of like Paul was saying.

In order for a company to
reach a big outcome in terms of big revenue
selling into defense,

they have to land what's
called a program of record. In the US, the way that we
spend money, as a nation, is that Congress approves
the spending, that,

kind of, determines the
market size and then companies have to get a piece of that.

That muscle among
startups has traditionally been very underdeveloped. And the reason for that is
because typically the six or so

prime defense
contractors in the US, they cover every
possible program office.

If a program manager
somewhere even has a daydream, there's somebody from a prime
writing that down on a napkin and putting stuff in front
of that program manager.

You can't run go to market
that way as a startup. You cannot cover
every program office. And so there has to be a new
playbook around how do you start

with an unfair advantage
you have in technology that the primes cannot compete in,
and then generate that market

and that demand in the form
of a program of record. And I would say in
the last 12 months, it feels like when you see
the program awards that

are going out and the talent
that we talk to on the go to market side, there's finally
like a strong base of operators

that have come up through that
playbook and can repeat it. And that's absolutely
necessary in order to get these products
into the right hands.

It's a-- the reason
why it's so hard is because it's a
three-headed sales process. The user, the person signing
off and the person funding it,

they're three different people. It's the only industry in the
world with this convince three people to buy a product.

And they don't
talk to each other. Nor care. They don't even know-- Nor care about each other. --each other exists.

It's a pretty wild system,
but that is the system. And I think the
startups are finally

starting to figure out
the playbook around that. And I wouldn't say that
knowledge is common yet, but at least it is emergent.

On the scary and
also important side, I would say doctrine
is massively

changing with respect to
ground warfare because of the use of drones. I think a lot of
people do understand

that that is a big product
and technology opportunity, but it's also a doctrinal
change that, I would say,

the United States
hasn't made yet. As a former infantryman,
I think about,

the videos that
we see coming out of Ukraine and the
intelligence that's coming out of Ukraine, if we ran
our patrols the way that we did

in Afghanistan, like
every one of those patrols would be a mass casualty event. And that's not going to be
a war winning motion for us.

Part of that solution
has to be technology but I think part of it also
has to be changes in doctrine and how we fight.

And I think we're at a very
interesting point where we're still making that transition. Yeah. So the Western general I got
to meet said, you going to--

this is going to either
scare you or make you happy. So it's a seven-minute
kill chain in Ukraine. So you leave your hiding
spot within two minutes,

you get classified by a
drone somewhere as a threat or an enemy or friend or foe.

And then five minutes,
something's coming at you. So you have seven minutes
to do what you need to do and then duck back in.

And then you've got to learn
how to dig trenches again, and you got to learn
how to look up. Yeah. I didn't realize.

It's like you guys are
all going this way, you got to look up now. So everyone's-- they had to
train their teams to look up all

the time, not normally around. So I want to come back to
a couple points made here.

So first of all, Paul's
first point about the speed of iteration that's going on
in the battlefield right now,

that cannot be overstated. It is happening. And what I think
the US military,

nor the Chinese military, nor
the Russian military have really absorbed yet is
because it's happening

that fast, decision
making is going to have to move to the edge.

You cannot have command and
control structure because things happen too quickly for that--

change too quickly for
that information thread to move from the field
up to Central Command,

say Pentagon and
back down again. And so I actually think
that's an advantage for the US

because as command and control
as the US DOD may feel like, it is actually a
much more distributed

organization than either
China or Russian military. So I think it's going to be an
advantage for the United States here.

But decision making
is moving to the edge, just like it is in all
of our AI architectures,

but it's going to move to
the edge in the military. The second thing I would
say about Dan's point is, it still
puzzles me that what

seems obvious to
all of us who spend time talking to folks in
Ukraine and in the Middle East

about this change in the
nature of the warfare still hasn't permeated the
command and control

architecture of the
United States DOD yet. And when you talk to them
about, so how much time

are the cadets at West Point
and the midshipmen at the Naval Academy spending using
drones, you get like,

well, maybe there's
one day a year where they get to play
in a field somewhere. When you go down to
Quantico and they're

training the next generation
of Marines, and you say, well, what are you doing with
drones and training.

Like oh, we can't use drones
in training because they interfere with helicopters. It's not safe. I'm like, well, you
think it's going

to be safe out in the
field if they don't know what to do with drones? So as obvious as it
seems to us, it's not

been internalized in
the US, DOD yet in ways that I think is very
dangerous for our soldiers.

So everyone's, of course,
talking about AI these days even outside of defense tech. How are you seeing
AI proliferate

across DOD and government? Maybe some specific examples of
companies you're working with.

I think this is an area where-- the AI hype has permeated
so many industries

that even in a place that's like
fairly resistant to technology, like DOD, I'm starting
to see the green shoots.

And so I think this is,
kind of, a hopeful question.  In the areas that seem
obvious, like autonomy,

we're starting to see it. You know certainly
companies like Shield AI are starting to get
real traction with DOD.

But it's also in areas where you
wouldn't necessarily immediately think of but there can
be really good effect.

A good example of that
is in things like mission planning and using large
language models to do things

like debriefs and after
action reports and things like that, that's all
intelligence that's

gathered from the field and it's
earned a very expensive way. And oftentimes, just because
of the nature of the military

and how often
those roles change, the sad thing is we go
out and fight like it's

the first time, many times. Whereas I think if we can be a
much better force at absorbing

intelligence and recalling
that intelligence in exactly the right time, place, it can
make us much more effective

and honor that intelligence
gathering and in a way that can make a difference. And so those are some ways
that I'm seeing it anyway,

that I think are
pretty promising. I think we're seeing
it across all parts of the military complex,
just like it is doing

for all other industry sectors. So whether it's writing RFPs
to bid on contracts using AI.

And so you hit a button
and you get an 85 page proposal pretty much done. These things are
like these beasts of a document, that's cool.

Or logistics, or
operational stuff. I think what we're focused
on is how can you get,

said capability,
into use faster.

And that's where we-- like to
point to this company called Helsing in Europe, which, partly
out of necessity and partly

because of approach, has been
able to bring modern software technology into assets
very, very quickly.

This company, I think
two years and two months from the founding,
won a program record.

The program of record
that Dan's talking about. The previous record
was Anduril three years to win a program of record,
which means you have a budgeted

line item in your government. So Helsing got a German
program of record in two years and two months to
put modern electronic warfare

software on the Eurofighter,
their marquee fighter jet. And that's really, really cool.

And they've since
replicated that playbook by partnering with the primes,
building great software,

hiring great AI people. People from Meta that didn't
know anything about government or military and going
after these missions,

probably because they have
to because they probably have the most advanced
European defense AI company.

So there are these really
exciting examples, Ernestine, of people bringing AI into the
military quickly getting cable

up and running very efficiently
that are really beacons for us to follow and learn from.

So I think the first area
that AI really penetrated the defense and
intelligence community was in image recognition.

So the US government
collects a ton of satellite imagery or
aerial-based imagery,

and didn't have enough humans
to look at it to figure out what was in it or not. So a lot of stuff that
they collected just

didn't get looked at. And they started to use computer
vision four or five, six or seven years ago I'm not
sure exactly when to do

that initial triage, if you
will, of what's interesting and what's not
interesting and what is interesting they
would then send it over

to the human analysts
to figure it out. And it had an
incredibly large impact.

The numbers I've seen in terms
of the amount of increased image processing, the amount of--

the shortness of time
from image capture to image being analyzed
by human when important.

All those metrics
were just phenomenal. It's penetrated into
some of the other areas. Certainly a lot of
the big data stuff

has leveraged AI now for a
couple of years in a lot of ways that Fortune 500 is
using AI to do it.

I think one of the hot
new areas right now, from the generative AI
perspective, is code assistance.

So these agencies have
a lot of developers and they're trying to
make them more efficient, just like the whole programming
industry is using through that.

So I think all those
things are great. If there's one area I'd point
to that still hasn't quite come to fruition despite some
of the hype around, I'd say,

is autonomy. The autonomous software
that's out there, I think isn't as mature as we would all
hoped it would have been by now.

And so I think that's a
really interesting opportunity for people to continue
make progress.

Yeah, it's not fully autonomous. There's still-- No. --a 99% problem. Maybe you could talk
a little bit more

about how you think about
evaluating and diligencing defense tech startups
to invest in. We touched upon like selling
into government is very hard.

For instance, how do you think
about a company's ability to sell into government and
also specifically for software

versus hardware startups. In the earliest stages,
which is where we invest,

it's all about the founders. And what we're looking for
in terms of founder DNA for a defense tech company
is primarily one, founding--

a founding team that
has deep user empathy. And that usually means
that one of the founders

has been in the military or been
in direct support of someone

in the military, somebody
who's, kind of, been there. Because I think
it's very hard to-- just it's such a
different world.

It's hard to imagine the product
that will really click and work in that workflow and
understand the challenges

and so forth without some
amount of direct exposure to what that world looks like.

And so that's one
thing we look for. Second thing we look for is
that go to market experience.

That's very, very
different for DOD. Selling into the government it's
a very different sales motion

than somebody who's built
a big software sales team, for example, that
sells commercially. And so I think there's a lot
of learning going on still.

So we don't expect somebody to
show up with the whole playbook, but it can't be the
first time they've heard of a program of
record, let me put it

that way, so we certainly look
for that as a second piece. And then the third
piece, of course, not in order of importance,
is real technologists.

When we are betting on a team
with venture dollars to have a massive outcome, there has to
be something that they can do

that the defense primes cannot
do and that is often technology.

If the primes can do what
the startup is trying to do, this is an industry that has
massive advantages to incumbency

and so we don't like
that shape of bet. We look for founding teams that
have that hardcore technologist

that can do something that very
few people on the planet can do. So if you look at Anduril
and Helsing, they have--

each of them have three
co-founders of the exact profile that Dan just outlined. And so yes, in a perfect
world, if everyone

had those three things
technology CEO background, go to market DOD
or German defense

and someone who knew AI
and the use case, amazing but that's going to
be a very rare set.

We see right now, and I don't
think this is the right answer, we see a lot of focus
on pedigree right now in the marketplace.

So I worked at Anduril. I've been there three years. I'm coming out. You can get a seed round
done really quickly.

Grab your friend from
SpaceX down in El Segundo. We're going to
build some hardware. And so there's a lot of--

I joke about this like there's
a lot of pedigree around that, which, if you look at the
history of venture capital,

where somebody
worked is not really a determinant of the outcome
because it's just not, right.

But there's a lot
of pedigree bias right now, good or bad,
because they do know a lot, they have the right
experience and they

can jump a lot of steps. The hardest thing
to figure out is who are the people
that have traveled

the furthest in their
journey to get to this point, to start a company.

And who can journey the
furthest in terms of aptitude or learning, and intensity
of that learning,

manifesting team capital
and product efficiently. And that is the hardest
part about venture, I think.

Because those people
are very rare, and they may come from
nowhere, you expect.

And that's sort of
like-- but I want to make sure people
understand there's the thing that Dan and I want to see,
ideally, three people walk in.

Yes, that's amazing. Or there's that person from
SpaceX, Tesla, Anduril, Palantir.

But then there's this other
journey type, that person that's just done so much work. The person that Steve and
I funded in semiconductors

never worked in semiconductors. The journey this person traveled
to learn that space was insane.

And the way this person has
hired this team of specialists from the industry is insane.

That is the archetype. It's not for everyone. But I think if you remember,
those three, you'll have a sense for where you
want to be and what you can do.

Yeah, I don't have a lot to add
to what Dan and Paul just said. I guess the one thing
they didn't mention

is I actually
think in this area, you also have to diligence
your co-investors as well.

Because as this
space has become hot, I think there are a
lot of tourists coming in who want to invest in defense
tech space, who don't really

understand how to build
a defense tech company. They want to build
in the same way that you build a
commercial tech company.

And I think that's different. In the commercial tech
world, typically, VCs want to fund them for 18 to
24 months, see some progress,

raise the next round of funding. In defense tech world,
it's hard to get meaningful progress in 18 to
24 months at the early stage.

I think a lot of companies
are getting funded that way and are coming up now for their
series A, series B investments,

and they don't have a lot
to show of what they do. And so I think you have
to fund your defense tech

companies in larger
chunks of time than you do with
commercial tech companies. I'm not sure every
investor realizes that.

So I think that's something
else we pay attention to. Maybe on that note, especially
for some of these later stage companies, how do you
think about valuations?

It feels like there's a lot
of defense tech companies that are getting valued at
more public tech company comps,

as opposed to public
defense prime comps. And just how do you think
about valuations in general.

Yeah so so Palantir
hit its all time high. It's like $97 billion. It's 27 times next
year's revenues,

which is twice as high
as any other software company in the world. So clearly there's
some AI hype there,

but there's, for sure, a company
that went from being, kind of, a laggard in terms of
valuation multiple at time

of direct listing
and the defense risk and all the other
crap around it to now

having the highest
valuation multiple tells you where things can go.

And so we're pretty excited
about that change in the market space. I think one giant
misnomer is our hardware.

In general public market
investors like software more than hardware. Software is high-margin, it's
recurring, it's easy to model,

it's really simple, you
have a lot of comps, hardware is less so. And I think you'll
see that shift in the next couple
of years where

people pay a premium for
software-defined hardware companies. Companies that make hardware
that are powered by software.

It might be lower
gross margins today, like an Anduril or a
Shield AI, but as they

scale and the margins scale
up, it'll actually be, frankly, even more valuable.

And I've written about
that on LinkedIn. And I think a lot of
people misunderstand the value of Anduril. They think they make hardware.

How can they be valued
at their last round? And I could clearly
articulate to you why, on an intrinsic
value basis,

it should be worth what it is. It just takes a few
more steps that you just have to understand that
business model shift.

I mean, selling hardware
products into the government has a higher lifetime value
than selling software.

They're going to buy this
stuff for 15, 20 years. It also doesn't cost you 100
software engineers to build it.

So you think about that
calculus and you sell it once, and you can scale it. So there's a lot of
really cool things

about software-defined hardware
if you can pull that off. Obviously, Tesla and SpaceX
are probably the two biggest

examples to look for. So Paul, your comments
remind me of-- Dan, maybe you
could speak to this

in terms of what Shield AI
has done in terms of starting with software, acquired Martin
UAV, packaged their software

around that. Kind of just thoughts on that,
and that as a general strategy for startups.

Absolutely. I think it actually
goes to something Paul said earlier as well, which
is that in defense tech land,

you have to think a little
bit more creatively. Yes in an ideal world,
you just compound revenue

the same way that a recurring
software business does, and you go out with
90% gross margins, and you're doubling like, great.

I think in defense land, a
lot of factors kind of change

the key inputs. One is the outsized
value of companies

that own programs of records
because they're so sticky. So sometimes it makes sense to
acquire your way in and then

upsell, if you will, the
better product that you've got. And that's, kind of,
what you're referring to with what Shield AI did.

They started as a company. At the heart of it,
they're a autonomy company

that builds the software
to control the hardware and make it autonomous.

But you can't really
sell autonomy software to the government. It's not like the
government's like oh, I've got all these things that are
just waiting for the software,

and please will someone
sell me the software. That's not how they think. They buy platforms and those
platforms are autonomous

or they're not. And so one thing that Shield
AI did a little bit differently

was they went out and
bought a Group 3 UAV manufacturer called Martin UAV.

And they ported their
software onto that product, and it became the only
autonomous Group 3

UAV in the market, which really
had a strong sales synergy.

It's hard to imagine
anyone buying a Group 3 UAV who's like, OK, OK, but
I don't want the autonomy.

Give me the one that
has no autonomy. Not many people are
going to say that. And so just that alone was a
big success story for Shield AI.

But I think that goes
back to your question of, hey, how-- are these
companies going to be,

valued, in terms of valuation,
multiple as a defense prime, which trades at a very
low valuation, multiple

or like a tech company? I think if you do the principal
component analysis on that,

really, it's actually,
from a finance perspective, two very unromantic things that
are the principal determinant

of a company's valuation
multiple, which is revenue growth and gross margins. If you really just run the
regression against those two

things, they are the
principal determinant of whether a company
trades at a rich multiple

or at a cheap multiple. And so it's no surprise that
the typical defense prime that's growing like 1% a
year and it's got 11% margins

or whatever, is going
to trade very poorly, and the tech company that's
going out doubling every year, 90% gross margins, it's--

It's actually the
increase in gross margin, just to be very clear,
it's not that you want to go to steady state. If your gross margins
can go up a lot,

then you have that
premium valuation. As opposed to if you
had 99% gross margins, and you went down to 90, it
actually would be different.

So it just makes
that point clear. Yeah. And so in a move like that,
there's a natural arbitrage.

Shield AI acquires a
company like Martin UAV, which on its own
without autonomy, is fairly
undifferentiated platform.

You probably can't
imagine it growing at an unnatural rate or
commanding an unnaturally high price.

But a startup with the truly
differentiating software aquires that, and it
can affect trajectory

on both of those
principal components, and it both unlocks higher
growth and better margins

and a richer valuation
multiple and then the returns start to
get pretty interesting.

So last question for me
before we turn it over to Q&A is, what advice do you have
for founders in the room

looking to build at the
intersection of technology and government?

Yeah, I think I'd come
back to some of the points my colleagues made here.

First off, if you want to build
a great company in this space, you have to
understand the problem that you're trying to solve.

I think Dan used the phrase
empathy for the problem.

So you have to-- and Paul may have talked about
passion for it, and the journey

to get there. So I think you have to really,
really understand the problem that you're trying to solve.

The next thing you
have to do is you have to build a team of
complementary skill sets.

Then you have to figure
out a funding structure to your company that matches the
ways in which the customer is

going to evaluate you, deem
that you've made progress and give you the next
milestone of customer support

that will allow you to raise
money at a higher valuation. So I think there's
a lot of things.

I also think, when we're
talking about defense-- we're a lot about
defense tech here. I still think there's
a lot of opportunity

So I think, in some
ways, you can oftentimes get some more
interesting revenue early on in the commercial sector
while you build a bigger,

more complex product for
the government use case. I think the aperture of
what to build here is huge.

I think we keep
talking about that. I mean, you could from
doing cyber to information warfare to all the systems we
were just talking about down

to making wire harnesses. So in order to put
a satellite in space or to build a fighter jet,
you need these wire harnesses,

which connect chips to sensors. And if the wire harness
is made too short, you're six months behind.

And so we invest
in a company that's making wire harnesses really
critical, really cool. Not the first thing
you think about.

So it's really
what is that you're interested and passionate
about and going very, very

deep in that journey. And then, in that
journey, you will find and understand where can
you transform and modernize

that thing. And then you have to go figure
out the sales part, the domain part. If you didn't serve, we
don't have top secret access,

but there's ways
to get around that. But you will find that there
are these really interesting problems that, if they could
just be fixed and transformed,

can make a meaningful
difference in the resilience of the US and its allies.

Not to get too meta
about this, but I feel like if you're going to do
it, I think you already know.

And here's what I mean. I think that when it
comes to something like defense and
defense tech, it

is such a
mission-driven decision that I don't think anyone can
talk you into it if you're not

interested in it,
and I don't think anyone could talk you out
of it if you've decided that that's your life passion.

And I think it's
very hard for anyone to come up with an
objective test around that. But I think if you really think
about it, you kind of know.

People who join the military,
for example, they probably don't do it for the
pay and so forth. I think they just kind of knew.

I think it's one of these
things where you ask the 20 whys or whatever, and then you get to
that point of like I don't know, I just feel that way.

And so I think defense tech
is one of those things. I would say it has all the
hallmarks of startup risk

and reward. And so not knowing whether
you will personally

have a successful outcome
or whether this whole wave of technology is going to have
a successful outcome or not,

you kind of have to pick based
on your own personal conviction. If you do this for the next
decade, which, by the way,

flies by really quickly, are
you going to look back and say,

hey, I'm really
glad that's how I spent a decade of my
most productive years regardless of outcome.

And I think to get to
that level of conviction, you kind of already
know or you don't.

On that note, questions
for our panelists? Question is, for a lot of
these defense tech companies,

it feels like it's either IPO or
bust, especially since there's a more limited M&A market.

Agree disagree. Thoughts on that. Go ahead. I was going to say
different investors can

look at it different ways. But implicit in what
I said about we only invest in companies
that we think can truly shift the
global superpower balance,

implicit in that is our
belief that there's not as robust an M&A
outcome for defense tech

companies at the moment. That could always change. Tech companies could start
acquiring defense tech companies. A lot could change.

But today, when I
look at the outcomes, it kind of feels like you got
to blaze a path to going public

otherwise, you're going to
be, a less interesting tuck in acquisition. And, as a result
of that, that's why

we rely so much on that success
case when we think about a deal.

I think we have obviously
a contrarian point of view. We think that the easy
industries are easy

and they're actually
not going to be ripe for value creation, meaning
enterprise software and B2C.

We think the hard stuff is where
it's going to make a difference. And, obviously, we think
defense, industrial energy

that is a critical point in the
thesis that you can get a 10x revenue multiple on
a hardware company,

not just a software company. And then you look
at the markets. Global defense market
is like $1.2 trillion.

Global industrial
market is 30% of GDP. Energy transition
is obviously huge. These are the last
remaining trillion dollar

markets that haven't been
touched by technology. And so, yeah, it's going to
be super hard, super ugly

along the way. But if you think about
the dollar opportunities to convert them into market
value, it's certainly there.

And I go back to
the Palantir point. SpaceX.

When Anduril goes,
it's going to be obviously a huge
outcome for that and pull a bunch of momentum.

And this whole industrial
base, which hasn't really been tapped, not to
digress, but like people don't realize some of the
greatest performing companies

in the last 10 years are
industrial manufacturing roll ups. Heico, Danaher,
TransDigm, L'Oréal Groupe.

These are some of the
highest-performing companies in stock market performance. And what do they do.

They make bits and parts
for the industrial base. So your question is a
really interesting one

and it's being bandied about
right now in the industry. Because if you're familiar with
the double hump hype cycle curve

that people talk
about, we're clearly on the backside
of the first hump where we're entering the
trough of disillusionment

and people are wondering
like, all right, there's been all this
hype about defense tech. What has it really done?

But I go back to 2000-- I have a long answer to
this question, by the way. So I think about a lot of time.

Going back to the
like time machine. Yeah, we're going
back to 2006 when there were two companies
that were starting

to get noticed by
venture capitalists and they were
SpaceX and Palantir.

And they looked very
different than the traditional venture-backed startup company. But people were, kind of,
intrigued by the team,

the technology and the
market, their opportu-- As an investor in Palantir
back then I got a lot of calls from top tier venture firms,
tell me about Palantir.

I like everything about
it except the market, because I don't
understand the market and I'm really nervous
about the market. And I tried my best
to explain to them,

the Palantir team tried
to explain it to them, but time and time again, the top
tier venture firms ultimately

passed on investing in
Palantir because they just didn't understand that market. And Palantir had to
really raise most

of its money from
non-traditional, early stage investors. SpaceX had its own path because
Elon was funding a lot of it

himself. But similarly, a lot of venture
funds kept looking at SpaceX

and being like, wow, I don't
know how to think about that. 10 years later, in 2015,
2016, all of a sudden

the venture capital
looked around and said, wow, those companies are worth
tens of billions of dollars and they can return a fund
for a venture capitalist.

And we all venture
capital is a hits driven, power law driven industry,
where 10% of the deals

will generate 70 to
75% of the returns. And so the venture capitalists
were all kicking themselves,

like, I just missed on
the exact type of deal that we're trying to invest in.

So that's when
defense tech started to become more interesting. And that next wave of--
because the venture capital

was, like, oh, how do I invest
in the next Palantir or SpaceX. And that next wave that I talked
about with Anduril and Shield

AI and Skydio and Vannevar
labs and all of them were started in that 2016,
2018, 2019 time frame.

But if you notice,
all those companies have great top tier
traditional investors in them.

Those companies are now
five, six, seven years old and they've raised a substantial
amount of money and none of them

have gotten to that
public outcome yet. None of them have achieved a
liquidity for their investors yet.

And so now everyone's
wondering, geez, I'm--

pick your metaphor,
all in a poker sense, I'm pregnant in another sense.

I'm really out there on the limb
of like I got a bunch of money into this sector and we haven't
achieved any liquidity yet.

And did I just
make a big mistake? And did I just cost my
fund a ton of money? I think Anduril is
absolutely going to get out.

I think Vannevar Labs is
absolutely going to get out. I think Shield AI and Skydio are
going to be valuable companies. I think they will all
eventually get there.

But we're in that
time, and this happens in every industry
where people-- this is when people start to get
nervous because they're really

exposed to where if
this doesn't work, they're kind of getting
fired from their firm. They're not being able to raise
their next fund for their firm

from LPs perspective. So there's some
nervousness there. I think the really interesting
question related to what you

asked, I told you I
had a long answer here, is if the traditional venture
business is hits driven

business, where 10% of the deals
generate 70%-75% of the def-- Is defense tech even
more concentrated?

Are there going to be fewer
winners, thus more concentrated in a smaller number of firms?

And what's the
consequence of that going to be for the industry? I think that's
really interesting. How many companies
are really going

to get to that
Palantir, Space X, Anduril stage of exit velocity?

I think that's
really interesting. A side note to your
question, though, is that the one place that M&A
is still happening is cyber. So if you characterize
that as defense tech,

there's a lot of M&A
still happening there. One more question. Yes. Yeah.

To repeat the question,
it's more just around stigma around
defense tech nowadays. What are your views now?

What are you seeing? How has that changed
from a few years ago? So I got a passionate answer
about this question also.

So, like I said, I've been in
this business for 18 years.

I think a lot of that
hype around Silicon Valley doesn't support defense
tech technologies,

they don't want to
be working on stuff that might be used to kill
people, target people, support warfare, all that sort of stuff.

And I think that
was way overhyped. We meet with a
thousand companies a year, have been for
the last 18 years.

Most of whom, to my earlier
point, are dual use technology. So they're not
companies that were started to go in that space.

And we come in associated
with the Central Intelligence Agency, which is not everyone's
favorite agency in the world.

And the number of companies
we meet with each year that say I'm a little uncomfortable
with what you guys do and what your customers
do is five or less.

So I think that
belief was really

concentrated in a small
number of insanely profitable consumer-facing
tech companies who

had a luxury that most
companies don't have of choosing who their customers are
or what businesses they're in because they were
making so much money.

And I think the whole Google,
Maven kerfuffle, which was probably the most
visible example of that,

was really poorly handled
by all parties involved. And I think if it had
been handled better, it wouldn't have
been such a big deal.

I do think as much
as I love Palantir, I think Palantir also overplayed
that thing because it was

a great message for them to
deliver to their customers look, the rest of Silicon
Valley hates you guys. We're the only company that
wants to do business with you.

Give us all your business. It was in Palmer and
Trae down at Anduril

picked up on that thing. And so it's self-serving
for all of them. And, again, I love
those guys as well.

But the vast majority of
Silicon Valley wants to help, I think because they're--
one they're patriotic. They want to help
these companies

in their mission of
keeping our country safe or these agencies in
keeping our country safe. Two their capitalistic.

They want to make
money, and they see this as a profitable
market to serve. And three they're
engineers and engineers

get geeked out by working
on the hardest problems. And some of these
problems that they're trying to solve here
for this community

are really hard
problems that they get excited about working with. So I think that
concern has always

been a little bit overblown. Paul, Dan, any other
thoughts on that? I think it's changed
dramatically.

In Europe, Helsing couldn't
raise around their first round of financing four years
ago and literally couldn't

get any money for the
business and now they're this darling of the
European VC marketplace.

But like all things, these
things go back and forth. And so what we're
concerned about is that when it swings back.

So now it's all hyped
up and it's all exciting but if there aren't the
outcomes in the next two years

or whatever, like geopolitics
takes a different turn, and we pull back from
the need to invest

in these critical industries
energy, defense, industrials, then we've lost
this special moment.

So I'm actually worried
about the opposite effect, not the former. Because we have enough energy
and momentum to do things,

we just need to
capitalize on it now. Yeah, I rooted-- I traced it back to a more call
it personal decision that lives

within each individual. I think, we live
in a country that has a volunteer military force.

And anybody can choose
to join the military or choose to not
join the military.

Similarly, everyone in this room
has tremendous opportunities.

You can think
about defense tech, and if you're fired up about it. And mission of the national
security of the United

States and its allies is
something that calls out to you, I think you know. I think you probably think, why
would I go do something else?

Why would I go sell software? That sounds way
less interesting. On the other hand,
if you're in the camp

where you're, kind of,
uncomfortable with that or you feel like, I don't
really get it or what have you,

everyone in this room is in a
tremendously privileged place where they have many other
opportunities that they

can go and pursue. And so I just feel like
that's one thing where

it does come down to the
conviction of the individual. I think this is a
polarizing enough thing

that the industry both
benefits and suffers from that polarization.

On the one hand, there
isn't this, kind of, mass market broad appeal. On the other hand, I think,
in tremendously mission driven

places, these organizations
can recruit people who--

and punch way above
their weight class compared to other places
that pay similarly,

let me put it that way. Because I think people who are
passionate about this mission will pursue this
mission and economics

take a secondary, kind
of, level of importance. And so all to say, I think
it's about the conviction

of the individual. I think this is the
thing that people do have very active thoughts on.

I don't think anybody
stumbles into it just finds themselves oh,
I just showed up, made

some random decisions
and ended up, working at a defense
tech company. I think it's a very
conviction-driven, decision.

On that note, we
are out of time, but we'll be around to
